meta.content: A rational combination of nanoscale reactions can offer complex nanostructures with multiple components. In the present study, a general synthetic protocol was developed to generate metal–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. Three well-known nanoscale reactions, Galvanic replacement, chalcogenization, and cationic exchange, were sequentially applied to the original Ag nanocubes, yielding PtAg, Pt–Ag2Se, and Pt–CdSe hollow nanocubes, respectively. The final structure was composed of two distinct layers of Pt and CdSe domains. Thin and continuous Pt inner layers were formed at the stage of selenization due to the nanoscale Kirkendall effect. With the variation of the metals (Pt, Au, and Pd) and metal selenides (Ag2Se, CdSe), six different metal–semiconductor hybrids were produced with an identical morphology of the double shell hollow nanocubes. Thicknesses of metal and CdSe layers were also regulated by controlling amounts of metal contents at the Galvanic replacement step. The resulting Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes effectively catalyzed photochemical hydrogen evolution reactions with long term stability.

meta.content: Metal–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes via Sequential Nanoscale Reactions and Their Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution - Topics in Catalysis

A rational combination of nanoscale reactions can offer complex nanostructures with multiple components. In the present study, a general synthetic protocol was developed to generate metal–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. Three well-known nanoscale reactions, Galvanic replacement, chalcogenization, and cationic exchange, were sequentially applied to the original Ag nanocubes, yielding PtAg, Pt–Ag2Se, and Pt–CdSe hollow nanocubes, respectively. The final structure was composed of two distinct layers of Pt and CdSe domains. Thin and continuous Pt inner layers were formed at the stage of selenization due to the nanoscale Kirkendall effect. With the variation of the metals (Pt, Au, and Pd) and metal selenides (Ag2Se, CdSe), six different metal–semiconductor hybrids were produced with an identical morphology of the double shell hollow nanocubes. Thicknesses of metal and CdSe layers were also regulated by controlling amounts of metal contents at the Galvanic replacement step. The resulting Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes effectively catalyzed photochemical hydrogen evolution reactions with long term stability.

div.p: Advertisement

div.div: Metal–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes via Sequential Nanoscale Reactions and Their Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution

header.h1: Metal–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes via Sequential Nanoscale Reactions and Their Photocatalytic Hydrogen Evolution
header.p:
Topics in Catalysis
volume
61
,
pages
965–976 (
2018
)
Cite this article

li.p:
441
Accesses

1
Citations

div.p:
A rational combination of nanoscale reactions can offer complex nanostructures with multiple components. In the present study, a general synthetic protocol was developed to generate metal–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. Three well-known nanoscale reactions, Galvanic replacement, chalcogenization, and cationic exchange, were sequentially applied to the original Ag nanocubes, yielding PtAg, Pt–Ag
2
Se, and Pt–CdSe hollow nanocubes, respectively. The final structure was composed of two distinct layers of Pt and CdSe domains. Thin and continuous Pt inner layers were formed at the stage of selenization due to the nanoscale Kirkendall effect. With the variation of the metals (Pt, Au, and Pd) and metal selenides (Ag
2
Se, CdSe), six different metal–semiconductor hybrids were produced with an identical morphology of the double shell hollow nanocubes. Thicknesses of metal and CdSe layers were also regulated by controlling amounts of metal contents at the Galvanic replacement step. The resulting Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes effectively catalyzed photochemical hydrogen evolution reactions with long term stability.

Materials at the nanometer scale have physical and chemical properties distinct from those of bulk states owing to their large surface area and limited structural dimensions [
1
,
2
]. In particular, a high surface-to-volume ratio causes the domination of the surface energy over the total structural energy [
3
]. As a result, solid state reactions on the surface directly couple with the final morphology of the nanomaterials. There are several representative nanoscale reactions inducing extreme versions of the morphology change. For instance, a Galvanic replacement reaction is usually known to be a cause of unwanted corrosion of metal frames, but when applied at the nanometer scale, it can generate hollow nanocages of various metals and metal oxides with a uniform size and thickness [
4
,
5
]. These hollow structures can also be generated via the nanoscale Kirkendall effect, as originally observed at the interface between coupled materials, forming excess vacancies during a non-equilibrium diffusion process [
6
,
7
]. Another intriguing reaction is cation exchange, which retains anionic sublattices in ionic solids, but exchanges cationic parts to diversify the compositions without altering the original shape [
8
,
9
].

Although these complex nanostructures have been widely investigated [
14
,
15
,
16
,
17
,
18
], applications of these materials remain limited. In fact, nanoscale reactions are highly sensitive to the choice of materials and the reaction conditions; thus, the reaction process tends to operate on a case-by-case basis and is not universal in terms of morphologies and compositions. In this aspect, a hollow nanocage is a successful option for potential applications. Xia and co-workers and Xia et al. employed Au hollow nanocages as versatile platforms for bio-imaging, photothermal therapy, drug release, and catalysis [
19
,
20
]. The hollow structure has an inner empty space in which materials are readily confined, and hollow walls of which materials can penetrate through defects and holes. Double shell hollow nanocages were also synthesized and used as catalysts for
p
-nitrophenol reduction [
21
,
22
]. We have also synthesized Pt–CdS hollow nanocubes and used them as a reaction chamber for the photocatalytic decomposition of lactic acid at a single particle level [
23
].

In the present study, we develop a general synthetic protocol of metal–semiconductor hollow nanocubes. The hollow cubes consist of metal inner shells and metal selenide outer shells which are separated by a clear interface. The synthetic approach involves three sequential nanoscale reactions as in Fig.
1
a: (1) a partial Galvanic replacement reaction forming a metal layer, (2) selenization with the Kirkendall effect generating double shells of metal and silver selenides with a complete hollow structure, and (3) cation exchange diversifying the semiconductor compositions (in this case, CdSe). Eventually, six metal–semiconductor hybrid structures are available to form uniform double shell hollow nanocubes, including Pt, Au, and Pd for the inner shells and Ag
2
Se, CdSe for the outer shells. The double shell hollow nanocubes are employed as a catalyst platform for photocatalytic hydrogen generation reactions.

a
general synthetic approach of metal–semiconductor double shell hollow nanocubes (M = Pt, Au and Pd). SEM and TEM images of
b
Ag nanocubes,
c
PtAg nanocubes,
d
Pt–Ag
2
Se and
e
Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. The bars represent 500 and 10 nm (inset)

div.h3: Synthesis of MAg Nanocubes (M = Pt, Au, Pd)
div.p:
Ag nanocubes with an average edge length of 56 nm were synthesized according to the literature [
27
]. An aqueous dispersion of Ag nanocubes (350 µmol with respect to the Ag precursor) was mixed with an aqueous solution of poly(vinylpyrrolidone) (PVP, 1.1 mmol, 120 mL). For the synthesis of PtAg nanocubes, an aqueous solution of H
2
PtCl
6
(18 μmol, 20 mL) was added to the reaction mixture at a rate of 1.0 mL min
−1
using a syringe pump at the reflux condition for 20 min. The mixture was allowed to stir at the reflux condition for additional 40 min. After the reaction, the product was collected by centrifugation, washed once with a saturated NaCl solution, and washed several times more with deionized water. The particles were dispersed in deionized water (30 mL) for further use. For the syntheses of AuAg and PdAg nanocubes, HAuCl
4
(24 µmol) and Pd(NO
3
)
2
(35 µmol) were used as metal precursors, otherwise the reaction conditions were identical to those of the PtAg nanocubes.
div.h3:
Synthesis of M–Ag
2
Se Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes
div.p:
For the synthesis of the Pt–Ag
2
Se double shell hollow nanocubes, an aqueous dispersion of PtAg hollow nanocubes (45 µmol with respect to the Ag precursor concentration) was mixed with an aqueous solution of PVP (230 µmol, 170 mL). An aqueous solution of selenourea (23 µmol, 4.5 mL) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at room temperature for 10 h in air. The product was collected by centrifugation and washed with deionized water several times. The particles were then dispersed in methanol (5.0 mL) for further use. For the syntheses of the Au–Ag
2
Se and Pd–Ag
2
Se double shell hollow nanocubes, the AuAg and PdAg hollow nanocubes were used instead of the PtAg hollow nanocubes, otherwise the reaction conditions were identical to those of the Pt–Ag
2
Se double shell hollow nanocubes.
div.h3: Synthesis of M–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes
div.p:
For the synthesis of the Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes, a methanol solution (0.11 mL) with dissolved PVP (34 µmol) and Cd(NO
3
)
2
(110 µmol) was added to a Pt–Ag
2
Se nanocube dispersion in methanol (1.1 mmol with respect to the Ag precursor), and the mixture volume was adjusted to 1.0 mL by the addition of methanol. The mixture was vigorously stirred at 50 °C for 10 min. Then, tributylphosphine (25 µL) was added, and the reaction mixture was stirred at 50 °C for 1 day. The product was collected by centrifugation, and washed with methanol several times. The particles were finally dispersed in methanol (1.0 mL) for characterization. For the synthesis of Au– and PdSe–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes, the Au– and Pd–Ag
2
Se nanocube dispersions were used under the identical reaction conditions, respectively. After the addition of tributylphosphine, the reaction mixture was stirred at 55 °C for 2 days. For the reduction of PdSe layer, hydrogen treatment was carried out at 300 °C for 30 min under the 4% H
2
+ 96% Ar mixed gas flowing condition.

For comparison, Pt–CdSe catalysts with commercial CdSe spheres were prepared by the photodeposition method. Commercial CdSe spheres (25 mg, Aldrich, < 10 µm diameter) and H
2
PtCl
6
(8.2 µmol) were mixed in a mixture of water (20 mL) and methanol (5 mL). The mixture was irradiated by Xe lamp (300 W, Oriel) for 30 min with vigorous stirring. The product was collected by centrifugation, and washed twice with deionized water.

The catalyst particles were dispersed in a 0.35 M Na
2
SO
3
/0.25 M Na
2
S aqueous solution (20 mL). The amount of the catalysts was fixed to 1.0 mg measured by a micro-balance. The reaction mixture was purged with N
2
gas for 40 min prior to the reaction. The hydrogen generation experiments were conducted using each sample with light irradiation by a Xe lamp (300 W, Oriel) equipped with a 10 cm IR filter. The reactor was a homemade quartz flask with a total volume of 40.5 mL which was sealed with a rubber septum. An aliquot of the reaction mixture was periodically collected by a syringe from a head space. The hydrogen amount was measured by a gas chromatograph (YL6100) with a thermal conductivity detector using argon as a carrier gas.

The Pt–CdSe hollow nanocubes were drop-casted on a SnO
2
/ITO electrode (5 mm × 5 mm) functionalized with mercaptopropionic acid. Photoelectrochemical (PEC) characterization was performed in a three electrode configuration with the Pt–CdSe/SnO
2
/ITO as the working electrode, a Pt wire counter electrode, and a Ag/AgCl reference electrode. The working electrode area exposed to the electrolyte was 0.28 cm
2
. A 150 W Xe lamp (Abet Technologies) was used as a light source. The PEC measurements were performed in a 0.35 M Na
2
SO
3
/0.25 M Na
2
S aqueous solution. In all tests, the intensity of the lamp on the sample was measured to be 100 mW/cm
2
. A monochromator (Oriel) was used to obtain action spectra (− 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl). Chopped light linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) was performed to obtain photocurrent responses using a DY2321 potentiostat (Digi-Ivy).

div.h3: Synthesis of Pt–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes
div.p:
Ag nanocubes with an average edge length of 56 ± 6 nm were synthesized via a modified polyol process in the presence of PVP (Fig.
1
b). With the addition of H
2
PtCl
6
solution, Pt deposition was formulated on the surface of Ag nanocubes via a Galvanic replacement reaction process. The standard reduction potential [1.000 V vs. standard hydrogen electrode (SHE)] of the Pt
4+
/Pt pair is higher than that (0.800 V vs. SHE) of the Ag
+
/Ag pair, promoting a spontaneous replacement reaction. The valency of Pt
4+
, four times larger than that of Ag
+
, results in void formation and expansion inside the nanocubes as the reaction goes on.

It was reported that pinhole-free AuAg hollow nanoboxes could be obtained by the addition of a Au precursor solution up to a molar ratio of 25:75 for Au and Ag; a further increase in the Au concentration initiated a dealloying process to create pinholes and destroy the hollow walls [
29
]. To retain the hollow cube framework and enough Ag content to proceed to the next reaction, the Pt precursor concentration was carefully adjusted. As a result, uniform PtAg nanocubes were yielded with an average edge length of 66 ± 6 nm (Fig.
1
c). An energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) analysis estimated the elemental atomic fractions of Pt and Ag to be 6.7 and 93.3%.

For the second step, the Ag residue which was not exchanged with Pt ions was converted to Ag
2
Se. With the addition of selenourea, Se
2−
was quickly released in situ and the oxidation of Ag occurred by O
2
in air as follows:

As shown in Fig.
1
d, the average size of the hollow cubes increased to 73 ± 8 nm. This was mainly attributed to the Kirkendall effect during the selenization. The atomic fractions of Ag and Se were estimated to be 62 and 34% by an EDX analysis, consistent with the full conversion of Ag to Ag
2
Se.

Eventually, Ag
2
Se was converted into CdSe via a cation exchange reaction with Cd
2+
. In this step, tributylphosphine was added as a phase-transfer agent to deliver Cd
2+
to the reaction sites [
8
,
12
]. Figure
1
e demonstrates that the morphology is still uniform, in the form of regular hollow cubes with an average edge length of 73 ± 6 nm. The atomic fractions of Cd and Se as estimated by the EDX analysis were 46 and 48%, which ensured the formation of CdSe. The fraction of Pt was measured to be 6%.

The complete conversion from PtAg to Pt–Ag
2
Se and to the Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes was evidenced by X-ray diffraction (XRD) data (Fig.
2
). The XRD spectrum of the PtAg hollow cubes has peaks which are nearly identical to those of face-centered cubic Ag (JCPDS #04-0783) due to the low fraction of Pt in the PtAg alloy. The XRD peaks of the Pt–Ag
2
Se hollow cubes correspond to the reflections of orthorhombic Ag
2
Se (JCPDS #25-0766). After the cation exchange reaction, the peaks assigned to hexagonal CdSe (JCPDS #08-0459) mainly appear in the spectrum. The single crystalline domain size of CdSe was calculated to be 11.7 nm from the broadness of the (002) reflection using the Scherrer formula. This reveals that the CdSe layer is polycrystalline with large single crystalline domains. There is a trace of Pt signals in the spectrum owing to the low loading content and polycrystalline nature of the Pt domains.

XRD spectra of PtAg hollow nanocubes and Pt–Ag
2
Se and Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes

Although the Pt loading amount was 6% versus the total amounts, it is surprising to note that the Pt component formed distinctive and continuous inner layers on the hollow walls. The dark-field image of an individual Pt–CdSe hollow nanocube shown in Fig.
3
a clearly shows that the hollow wall consists of a bright inner layer with an average thickness of 3 nm and a grey outer layer with 10 nm. The bright-field image in Fig.
1
e also represents the distinct inner and outer shells of an individual hollow cube. A high resolution TEM (HRTEM) image of the interface region between the two layers includes two different lattice fringe images (Fig.
3
b), of which the inner shell has an average distance between adjacent fringes of 0.23 nm, in good agreement with the distance of face-centered cubic Pt(111) planes. The average distance of 0.37 nm between the fringe images in the outer shell corresponds to the distance between the hexagonal CdSe(100) planes. EDX elemental mapping confirms the double shell formation of the hollow walls. The Cd (yellow) and Se (red) signals cover all ranges of the walls (Fig.
3
d, e), and the Pt (green) signals are mainly located on the inner side of the walls (Fig.
3
f). The mapping of the total elements demonstrates a clear distinction of the inner Pt shell and the outer CdSe shell (Fig.
3
c). The point EDX spectra at the outer and inner shells also note the local confinement of the Pt element in the inner shell region of the hollow cubes (Fig. S1).

a
HAADF–STEM and
b
HRTEM images, and
c
–
f
EDX elemental mapping of Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. The bar in
b
represents 4 nm

div.h3: A Key Process of Double Shell Hollow Formation
div.p:
To clarify the important reaction step in which the double shells were formed during the three consecutive processes, the selenization and cation exchange processes were investigated in detail. After the first step of the partial Galvanic replacement, PtAg nanocubes were produced (Fig.
4
b). The point EDX analysis of an individual cube indicated that the outer region near the surface was relatively Pt-rich (Pt:Ag = 27:73) with Ag-rich cores (Pt:Ag = 7:93) (Fig. S2), consistent with the deposition of the Pt component on the surface of Ag cubes [
22
]. Due to the small amount (7%) addition of Pt, the core region did not completely become empty, but the significant Ag component remained with irregular pores and vacancies, which may lead to show the low contrast in Fig.
4
b. In the second step, the selenization reaction was partially carried out by the addition of a smaller amount of the Se precursor solution. The resulting hollow cubes had multiple compositions of Pt, Ag, and Ag
2
Se in which no distinct layers were observed on the hollow wall, although the total wall thickness increased (Fig.
4
c). After the completion of the selenization reaction, two layers began to appear with a distinct contrast in the hollow wall (Fig.
4
d). The layers were more distinguishable in the hollow nanocubes after the partial and full cation exchange reactions, due to the change of outer layers from Ag
2
Se to CdSe, which lowered the density from 8.141 to 5.663 g cm
−3
(Fig.
4
f). These observations indicate that the formation of the distinctive double shell structure was mainly attributed to the Kirkendall effect during the selenization process, by the comparison of Fig.
4
c, d. In the literature, the nanoscale Kirkendall effect was initially investigated during the sulfidation of Co particles [
8
]; it was also observed during the hollow formation of Ag
2
Se due to the selenization of Ag nanoparticles. The present example differs from the previous examples, in that the original PtAg cubes were alloys and not perfectly single crystalline materials. By the in-situ addition of Se
2−
, the Ag component in the PtAg alloy was selectively converted to Ag
2
Se on the surface, during which Ag continuously diffused from the alloy to the surface and formed more Ag
2
Se. The diffusion rate of Ag is faster than that of Se
2−
at the Ag
2
Se interface; thus, Ag
2
Se was preferentially grown on the outer surface [
30
]. The Pt atoms were relatively confined to the inner region and were reorganized into a continuous polycrystalline inner layer. It should be noted that the Pt composition was mainly distributed on the surface of the PtAg hollow nanocubes, but by the continuous diffusion of Ag onto the surface during the selenization, the Pt was eventually located at the inner walls. The total wall thickness increased due to the growth of Ag
2
Se on the outer shells. Because the original PtAg hollow cubes had many defects, the voids were released during the process; thus, the Ag
2
Se outer shell came into contact with the Pt inner shell without any gaps appearing at the interface [
31
].

TEM images of individual nanostructures along the reaction progress.
a
Ag nanocube,
b
PtAg alloy hollow nanocubes by partial Galvanic replacement,
c
PtAg–Ag
2
Se hollow nanocube by partial selenization,
d
Pt–Ag
2
Se hollow nanocube by complete selenization,
e
Pt–Ag
2
Se/CdSe hollow nanocube by partial cation exchange, and
f
Pt–CdSe hollow nanocube by complete cation exchange

The formation of the Pt layers is also important to retain the hollow cube framework during the reaction process. Without a Pt layer, the Ag cubes cannot maintain their structure, instead taking on an irregular shape due to the severe surface dissolution which occurs during the selenization process.
div.h3: Adjustment of the Pt Loading Content
div.p:
The Pt loading content of each double shell hollow nanocube was adjusted by adding a different amount of the Pt precursor during the Galvanic replacement step. The Pt loading could be increased up to 23% for the PtAg hollow nanocubes, and with the sequential reactions, the Pt loading contents of the resulting Pt–Ag
2
Se, and Pt–CdSe hollow nanocubes were 13, and 16%, respectively. The morphology of each nanostructure remained a hollow cube with a double shell (Fig.
5
). However, when a larger amount of the Pt precursor was added during the first step, pinholes were generated on the walls of the hollow nanocubes, as the Galvanic replacement reaction exceedingly proceeded throughout the hollow formation process, and the dealloying process began.

SEM and TEM images of
a
PtAg hollow nanocubes, and
b
Pt–Ag
2
Se and
c
Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes with large Pt loading contents.
d
Pt metal contents during sequential reactions (inset) TEM images of individual hollow nanocubes. The bars represent 500 nm

div.h3: Photocatalytic Hydrogen Generation using Pt–CdSe Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes
div.p:
Previous research has reported that the metal–semiconductor double shell hollow nanostructures showed higher photocatalytic activity and stability in photocatalytic hydrogen evolution [
16
,
32
]. The Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes were also employed as a photocatalyst for hydrogen evolution in a 0.35 M Na
2
SO
3
/0.25 M Na
2
S aqueous solution under the UV–Vis irradiation (Fig.
6
). For the comparison of photocatalytic activity, Pt was photochemically deposited on commercially available CdSe spheres (Fig. S3). Under the present conditions, the double shell hollow nanocubes showed a linear increase of the hydrogen generation along the reaction progress, and the activity was estimated to be 27.5 mmol g
−1
h
−1
(Fig.
6
a). This value is superior to the activity of 21.8 mmol g
−1
h
−1
for the Pt-deposited CdSe spheres, presumably due to the well-organized structure of the Pt and CdSe double layers.

a
Photocatalytic hydrogen evolution using Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes (black) and photochemically platinized commercial CdSe spheres (red).
b
Time course of hydrogen evolution using Pt-CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes.
c
LSV and
d
action spectrum of the Pt–CdSe electrodes in a 0.35 M Na
2
SO
3
/0.25 M Na
2
S aqueous solution

The photocatalytic stability of the Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes were tested. The gas samples in the reactor were analyzed every 30 min with repetitive N
2
purging every 2 h. The photocatalytic activity did not significantly decrease for prolonged UV–Vis irradiation, and maintained 89% of the initial activity even after 10 h (Fig.
6
b). The TEM image of the catalyst particles indicated that the morphology of the double shell hollow structure maintained during the reaction (Fig. S4). Such a high stability is remarkable compared to the other photocatalysts [
17
], due to the structural confinement of the Pt co-catalysts inside the CdSe outer shells, behaving as mechanically strong frames. The effective photogenerated hole transfer to the sulfides through the external surface of the CdSe outer shells may also suppress the oxidation of CdSe at the interface and the resulting detachment of Pt co-catalysts [
24
,
33
,
34
].

It is known that the sulfite reduction on semiconductors shows perfect transfer efficiency by the fast electron transfer rate during the PEC measurements [
32
]. The Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes were deposited on a SnO
2
/ITO electrode [
35
], and the photoresponse was measured by the UV–Vis irradiation in the presence of Na
2
S and Na
2
SO
3
as sacrificial reagents. Figure
6
c represents the generation of anodic photocurrents, originated from n-type characteristics of the CdSe electrode. The photocurrent density was measured to be 0.8 mA cm
−2
at − 0.5 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The action spectrum of the double shell hollow nanocubes exhibits the wavelength dependency of the photocurrent generation (Fig.
6
d).
div.h3: General Synthesis of M–CdSe (M = Au and Pd) Double Shell Hollow Nanocubes
div.p:
The present synthetic scheme could be generalized for other noble metals, such as Au and Pd. The sequential three step process via partial Galvanic replacement, selenization, and cation exchange was identical to the synthesis of the Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes, except for the use of either HAuCl
4
as an Au precursor or Pd(NO
3
)
2
as a Pd precursor.

For the Au–CdSe structures, during the first step of partial Galvanic replacement, AuAg nanocubes were produced with a 14% atomic fraction of Au. The selenization process yielded Au–Ag
2
Se hollow nanocubes (Fig.
7
c), and the subsequent cation exchange reaction with Cd
2+
ions generated Au–CdSe hollow nanocubes (Fig.
7
e). TEM images of individual nanoparticles show that the hollow walls are composed of two distinct layers with the dark Au inner shells (Fig.
7
e inset). The atomic fraction of the Au–CdSe hollow cubes was measured to be 6:50:44 for Au, Cd, and Se. The XRD spectrum shows the combination of face-centered cubic Au (JCPDS #04-784) and hexagonal CdSe diffraction patterns (Fig. S4). From the Scherrer formula, the average single crystalline CdSe domain sizes were calculated to be 10.6 nm.

SEM images of
a
AuAg and
b
PdAg nanocubes,
c
Au–Ag
2
Se and
d
PdSe–Ag
2
Se double shell hollow nanocubes. SEM and TEM images of
e
Au–CdSe and
f
PdSe–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes. The bars represent 500 and 10 nm (insets)

For the Pd–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes, the Pd loading content was measured to be 13% for the PdAg nanocubes. Double shell hollow nanocubes were also formed via subsequent selenization and cation exchange reactions (Fig.
7
d, f). The TEM image of an individual nanoparticle represents the successful formation of distinct double layers on the hollow walls (Fig.
7
f inset). At the selenization process, however, the PdSe inner shells were unexpectedly yielded instead of Pd. The XRD spectrum of the double hollow nanocubes in Fig.
8
c shows more complex diffraction patterns than the simple combination of Pd and CdSe diffractions. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (Fig.
8
d, upper) shows that all Pd species exist as Pd(II), which is indicative of the PdSe formation. Consequently, the composition of the final product is assigned as the PdSe–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes.

a
SEM and
b
TEM image of Pd–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes
c
XRD patterns and
d
XPS spectra of PdSe–CdSe and Pd–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes

To obtain the desired Pd–CdSe hollow nanocubes, further treatment is required for the reduction of PdSe layers. The PdSe–CdSe hollow nanocubes were treated with H
2
flow at 300 °C for 30 min (Fig.
8
a, b). After the treatment, the particle morphology was unchanged without severe agglomeration. The atomic fractions were measured to be 17:41:42 for Pd, Cd, and Se. The XRD pattern is now assignable to the sum of face-centered cubic Pd (JCPDS #46–0784) and hexagonal CdSe signals. (Figs.
8
c and S4). From the Scherrer formula, the average single crystalline domain sizes were calculated to be 15.4 nm. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) signals clearly shifted to the low energy region, and were assignable to the Pd(0) species, indicating the successful formation of the Pd–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes (Fig.
8
d, lower spectrum).

A general synthetic protocol including three sequential nanoscale reactions, partial Galvanic replacement, selenization, and cationic exchange, was developed to synthesize uniform metal–semiconductor double shell hollow nanocubes. The resulting structure is composed of two distinct layers in the hollow walls, metal inner shells and semiconductor outer shells, with a clear interface between the two. The continuous and distinctive metal inner shells mainly formed during the stage of selenization via the nanoscale Kirkendall effect. The resulting Pt–CdSe double shell hollow nanocubes were applied to the photocatalytic H
2
evolution. The photocatalytic activity was > 20% larger than that of the photodeposited catalysts with long-term stability. The spatial separation of the metal (exposed inward) and semiconductor (exposed outward) layers in this well-organized metal–semiconductor double shell hollow morphology could distinguish the light absorption and hydrogen evolution sites with effective transfer of photogenerated electrons through well-defined junctions. This morphology also gained a big benefit from the separation of reduction and oxidation sites, which blocked unwanted oxidation at the interface and prevent the oxidative detachment of the metal components from the catalysts.

In this nanoscale synthesis, metal loading contents were controllable during the Galvanic replacement step. Moreover, variation of the metals (Pt, Au, and Pd) and semiconductors (Ag
2
Se and CdSe) could yield six different combinations with identical double shell hollow nanocube structures. An additional choice of the metal ion, such as Zn
2+
, Cu
2+
, and Pb
2+
during the cationic exchange step [
9
,
36
], would lead to the reaction of a series of metal–semiconductor double shell hollow nanocubes. This will clarify the composition effect on various heterogeneous catalytic reactions and clearly separate it from other unknown factors. It will eventually be helpful to optimize the catalysts’ composition and morphology for chemically significant reactions.
